text: I have come to my garden, my sister bride,
I have gathered my myrrh with my spice,
I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey,
I have drunk my wine with my milk!
Eat, O friends! ⸤Drink and become drunk \add with\add* love⸥!\f + \fr 5:1 \ft Or “Drink and become drunk, O lovers!” \f*
Maiden’s Dream: Seeking and Not Finding
I \add was\add* asleep but\f + \fr 5:2 \ft Or “and” \f* my heart was awake.
A sound! My beloved knocking!\f + \fr 5:2 \ft Or “The sound of my beloved knocking!” \f*
“Open to me, my sister, my beloved,
my dove, my perfect one!
For my head is full of dew,
⸤my hair drenched from the moist night air⸥.”\f + \fr 5:2 \ft Literally “my locks with drops of night” \f*
I have taken off my tunic, ⸤must I put it on⸥?\f + \fr 5:3 \ft Literally “How will I put it on?” \f*
I have bathed my feet, ⸤must I soil them⸥?\f + \fr 5:3 \ft Literally “How will I soil them?” \f*
My beloved thrust his hand into the opening,
and my inmost yearned for him.
I myself arose to open to my beloved;
my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh
upon the handles of the bolt.
I opened myself to my beloved,
but my beloved had turned and gone;\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Or “my beloved had left; he was gone” \f*

my heart sank\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Or “my soul left” \f* when he turned away.\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Or “when he was speaking.” Translations equivocate on how to translate this verb, since there are two terms in Hebrew spelled identically: “to speak” and “to turn aside” (HALOT 1:210). The context suggests the latter \f*
I sought him, but I did not find him;
I called him, but he did not answer me.
The sentinels making rounds in the city found me;
they beat me, they wounded me;
they took my cloak\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Or “mantle” \f* away from me—
⸤those sentinels on the walls⸥!\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Literally “the sentinels of the walls” \f*
Adjuration Refrain
I adjure you, ⸤O maidens of Jerusalem⸥,\f + \fr 5:8 \ft Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem” \f*
if you find my beloved, what will you tell him?
\add Tell him\add* that I am ⸤lovesick⸥!\f + \fr 5:8 \ft Literally “sick \fq with \ft love” \f*
Maiden’s Praise of Her Beloved
⸤How is your beloved better than another lover⸥,\f + \fr 5:9 \ft Literally “What \fq is \ft your beloved more than \fq another \ft beloved …?” \f*
O most beautiful among women?
⸤How is your beloved better than another lover⸥, \f + \fr 5:9 \ft Literally “What \fq is \ft your beloved more than \fq another \ft beloved …?” \f*
that you adjure us thus?
My beloved \add is\add* radiant and ⸤ruddy⸥,\f + \fr 5:10 \ft Literally “red” \f*
distinguished ⸤among⸥\f + \fr 5:10 \ft Literally “more than” \f* ten thousand.
His head \add is\add* gold, refined gold;
his locks \add are\add* wavy, black as a raven.
His eyes \add are\add* like doves beside springs\f + \fr 5:12 \ft Or “streams” \f* of water,
bathed in milk, ⸤set like mounted jewels⸥.\f + \fr 5:12 \ft Literally “dwelling in a setting” \f*\f + \fr 5:12 \ft Or “seated at a \fq suitable \ft mounting” \f*
His cheeks \add are\add* like beds of spice, a tower of fragrances;
his lips \add are\add* lilies dripping liquid myrrh.
His arms \add are\add* ⸤rods⸥\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Literally “cylinders” \f*\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Or “rings” \f* of gold ⸤engraved with⸥\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Literally “filled with” \f* jewels;
his belly\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Or “body” \f* \add is\add* polished ivory covered with sapphires.\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Or “works of ivory set with sapphire” \f*
His legs \add are\add* columns of alabaster,\f + \fr 5:15 \ft Or “marble” \f* set on bases of gold;
his appearance \add is\add* like Lebanon, choice as ⸤its cedars⸥.\f + \fr 5:15 \ft Literally “the cedars” \f*
⸤His mouth⸥\f + \fr 5:16 \ft Or “his palate” \f* \add is\add* sweet,
and he is altogether desirable.
This \add is\add* my beloved;
this \add is\add* my friend, ⸤O young women of Jerusalem⸥.\f + \fr 5:16 \ft Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem” \f*
